newsitem.title: FRANCE: France, Germany can have different policy - Giscard.
newsitem.headline: France, Germany can have different policy - Giscard.

text.p: Former French president Valery Giscard d'Estaing said on Wednesday France and Germany can follow different monetary policies.

Speaking in a parliamentary debate on European Union, Giscard said, "These policies must be closely coordinated, it is clear that they are, but they must not be surbordinated, that is to say, one does not necessarily have to follow the other."
"They are undertaken in two different national contexts," Giscard said. "Different factors, distinct policies, but with the same objectives."
Giscard d'Estaing said France and Germany are facing different economic situations and this justified different monetary policies.
"Germany must still support, for several years, the heavy cost of its reunification, which weighs on its interest rate policy," he said.
"France, for its part, must imperatively return to growth and cut its unemployment to enter monetary union in good health," he said.

Giscard d'Estaing congratulated successive French governments for giving the franc its credibility. He said credibility was a necessary element to restore the French position at the heart of monetary union.
"But let us not make the mistake of confusing that credibility with a particular exchange rate. It rests on the fundamentals of our economy," he said.
"That credibility in no way imposes on us a need to follow another currency to determine our rate of entry in monetary union."
